  The argument assumes that the only factor contributing to the difference in colon cancer rates between Western and non-Western countries is the difference in fiber intake.
  The argument does not consider other factors that could be contributing to the higher colon cancer rates in Western countries, such as differences in lifestyle, genetics, or environmental factors.

### Temperature: 5.0 | Problem 51 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Journalist: A manufacturers' trade group that has long kept its membership list secret inadvertently sent me a document listing hundreds of manufacturing companies. A representative of the trade group later confirmed that every company listed in the document does indeed belong to the trade group. Because Bruch Industries is not listed on the document, it is evidently not a member of the trade group.
Question: The journalist's reasoning in the argument is flawed in that the journalist
Choices:
  A: gives no reason to think that Bruch Industries would want to belong to the trade group
  B: does not present any evidence that the document names every member of the trade group
  C: does not explain how it is that the trade group could have inadvertently sent out a secret document
  D: presents no reason why Bruch Industries would not want its membership in the trade group to be known
  E: takes for granted the accuracy of a statement by a representative who had a reason to withhold information
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The journalist received a document that lists hundreds of manufacturing companies.
  The manufacturers' trade group has long kept its membership list secret.
  A representative of the trade group confirmed that every company listed in the document belongs to the trade group.
  Bruch Industries is not listed in the document.
Thought:
  The journalist received a document containing a list of hundreds of manufacturing companies.
  The trade group confirmed that every company listed in the document belongs to the trade group.
  Bruch Industries is not listed in the document.
  Therefore, Bruch Industries is not a member of the trade group.
  The journalist's reasoning is sound.
  None of the choices accurately describe a flaw in the journalist's reasoning.
Action: Answer("None of the Above")

### Temperature: 5.0 | Problem 52 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Modest amounts of exercise can produce a dramatic improvement in cardiovascular health. One should exercise most days of the week, but one need only do the equivalent of half an hour of brisk walking on those days to obtain cardiovascular health benefits. More vigorous exercise is more effective, but a strenuous workout is not absolutely necessary.
Question: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the statements above?
Choices:
  A: Having a strenuous workout most days of the week can produce a dramatic improvement in cardiovascular health.
  B: Doing the equivalent of an hour of brisk walking two or three times a week generally produces dramatic improvements in cardiovascular health.
  C: It is possible to obtain at least as great an improvement in cardiovascular health from doing the equivalent of half an hour of brisk walking most days of the week as from having a strenuous workout most days of the week.
  D: Aside from exercise, there is no way of improving one's cardiovascular health.
  E: To obtain a dramatic improvement in one's cardiovascular health, one must exercise strenuously at least occasionally.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  Modest amounts of exercise can produce a dramatic improvement in cardiovascular health.
  One should exercise most days of the week, but one need only do the equivalent of half an hour of brisk walking on those days to obtain cardiovascular health benefits.

### Temperature: 5.0 | Problem 53 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Leatherbacks, the largest of the sea turtles, when subjected to the conditions of captivity, are susceptible to a wide variety of fatal diseases with which they would never come in contact if they lived in the wild. It is surprising, therefore, that the likelihood that a leatherback will reach its theoretical maximum life expectancy is about the same whether that animal is living in captivity or in the wild.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to resolve the apparent discrepancy?
Choices:
  A: Fewer diseases attach leatherbacks than attack other large aquatic reptiles.
  B: The average life expectancy of sea turtles in general is longer than that of almost all other marine animals.
  C: Most leatherbacks that perish in the wild are killed by predators.
  D: Few zoologists have sufficient knowledge to establish an artificial environment that is conducive to the well-being of captive leatherbacks.
  E: The size of a leatherback is an untrustworthy indicator of its age.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  Leatherbacks, the largest of the sea turtles, are susceptible to fatal diseases when in captivity.
  Leatherbacks in captivity are susceptible to diseases that they would not encounter in the wild.
  The likelihood of a leatherback reaching its theoretical maximum life expectancy is about the same whether living in captivity or in the wild.
Thought:
  The paradox is that leatherbacks in captivity are susceptible to fatal diseases that they would not encounter in the wild, yet the likelihood of reaching their maximum life expectancy is about the same whether living in captivity or in the wild. 
  Therefore, it is necessary to find an option that explains why the life expectancy of leatherbacks is the same in captivity and in the wild despite the fact that leatherbacks are susceptible to fatal diseases in captivity that they would not encounter in the wild.
  A: This option provides information about the susceptibility of leatherbacks to diseases in comparison to other aquatic reptiles, but it does not explain why leatherbacks in captivity have the same life expectancy as those in the wild.
  B: This option provides information about the life expectancy of sea turtles in general, but it does not explain why leatherbacks in captivity have the same life expectancy as those in the wild.
  C: This option provides information about the causes of death of leatherbacks in the wild, but it does not explain why leatherbacks in captivity have the same life expectancy as those in the wild.
  D: This option provides information about the ability of zoologists to create a suitable environment for captive leatherbacks, but it does not explain why leatherbacks in captivity have the same life expectancy as those in the wild.
  E: This option provides information about the reliability of the size of a leatherback as an indicator of its age, but it does not explain why leatherbacks in captivity have the same life expectancy as those in the wild.
  Therefore, none of the options helps to resolve the apparent discrepancy.
Action: Answer("None of the above")
Response 1:
Knowledge:
  Leatherbacks are susceptible to fatal diseases when in captivity.
  Leatherbacks are susceptible to diseases they would not encounter in the wild.
  The likelihood of a leatherback reaching its maximum life expectancy is similar in captivity and in the wild.
Thought:
  The argument states that leatherbacks are susceptible to fatal diseases in captivity, but the likelihood of reaching maximum age is similar in captivity and in the wild. 
  This suggests that there must be some other factor that offsets the increased disease risk in captivity.
  Option A is irrelevant to the argument.
  Option B is also irrelevant to the argument.
  Option C suggests that predators are a significant factor in reducing the lifespan of leatherbacks in the wild, which could explain why the likelihood of reaching maximum age is similar in captivity and in the wild.
  Option D is irrelevant to the argument.
  Option E is also irrelevant to the argument.
  Therefore, the answer is C: Most leatherbacks that perish in the wild are killed by predators.
Criticism:
  It is possible that the predators that kill leatherbacks in the wild are not present in captivity, which would also explain the similar likelihood of reaching maximum age in captivity and in the wild.

  Leatherbacks have the same likelihood of reaching their maximum life expectancy whether in captivity or in the wild.

Context: It is likely that most of the new television programs Wilke & Wilke produce for this season will be canceled. Most of the new shows they produced last season were canceled due to insufficient viewership. Question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to strengthen the argument?
Choices:
  A: Wilke & Wilke have produced more new shows for this season than they produced last season.
  B: Most of the shows that Wilke & Wilke produced last year were police dramas.
  C: None of the shows that Wilke & Wilke produced last year that were not canceled were police dramas.
  D: All of the new shows that Wilke & Wilke produced last year that were canceled were police dramas.
  E: None of the most popular television shows last year were police dramas.

Topic: Law
Context: History provides many examples of technological innovations being strongly resisted by people whose working conditions without those innovations were miserable. This shows that social inertia is a more powerful determinant of human behavior than is the desire for comfort or safety.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously undermines the reasoning in the argument?
Choices:
  A: People correctly believe that technological innovations often cause job loss.
  B: People are often reluctant to take on new challenges.
  C: Some examples of technological innovation have been embraced by workers.
  D: People tend to adapt easily to gradually implemented technological innovations.
  E: People correctly believe that technological innovations almost always increase workers' productivity.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The argument claims that social inertia is a more powerful determinant of human behavior than is the desire for comfort or safety.
Thought:
  The argument is based on the premise that people resist technological innovations due to social inertia.
  However, if there are examples where people have embraced technological innovations, then the argument would be weakened.
  Therefore, C is the answer.
Criticism:
  None.
Action: Answer("C")

  Choice E is not relevant to the argument.

### Temperature: 5.0 | Problem 57 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Harrold Foods is attempting to dominate the soft-drink market by promoting "Hero," its most popular carbonated drink product, with a costly new advertising campaign. But survey results show that, in the opinion of 72 percent of all consumers, "Hero" already dominates the market. Since any product with more than 50 percent of the sales in a market is, by definition, dominant in that market, Harrold Foods dominates the market now and need only maintain its current market share in order to continue to do so.
Question: The argument commits which one of the following errors in reasoning?
Choices:
  A: failing to exclude the possibility that what appears to be the result of a given market condition may in fact be the cause of that condition
  B: mistaking a condition required if a certain result is to obtain for a condition that by itself is sufficient to guarantee that result
  C: treating the failure to establish that a certain claim is false as equivalent to a demonstration that that claim is true
  D: taking evidence that a claim is believed to be true to constitute evidence that the claim is in fact true
  E: describing survey results that were obtained in the past as if they are bound to obtain in the future as well
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  Harrold Foods is promoting "Hero," its most popular carbonated drink product, with a costly new advertising campaign.
  Survey results show that, in the opinion of 72 percent of all consumers, "Hero" already dominates the market.
  Any product with more than 50 percent of the sales in a market is, by definition, dominant in that market.
Thought: 
  The argument claims that Harrold Foods dominates the market now and need only maintain its current market share in order to continue to do so.
  The argument uses survey results to support its claim.
  However, the argument commits an error in reasoning.
  The argument assumes that the survey results will remain constant in the future, which may not be true.
  Therefore, the argument commits the error of describing survey results that were obtained in the past as if they are bound to obtain in the future as well.
  The answer is E: describing survey results that were obtained in the past as if they are bound to obtain in the future as well.
Criticism: 
  The argument assumes that the survey results will remain constant in the future, which may not be true.
  However, the argument does not commit any of the other errors in reasoning listed in the answer choices.

  Therefore, the argument commits the error of assuming that past survey results will necessarily hold true in the future.
Action: Answer("E")
Response 9:

  Harrold Foods is promoting "Hero," its most popular carbonated drink product, with a costly new advertising campaign.
  Survey results show that 72% of all consumers believe that "Hero" already dominates the market.
  Any product with more than 50% of the sales in a market is, by definition, dominant in that market.

  The argument concludes that Harrold Foods dominates the market now and will continue to do so.
  The argument uses the survey results to support the conclusion that Harrold Foods dominates the market.
  However, the survey results only show that 72% of consumers believe that "Hero" dominates the market, not that it actually does.
  The argument assumes that the belief of consumers is equivalent to the actual market share of "Hero."
  This is an error in reasoning because the argument does not provide evidence that "Hero" actually has more than 50% of the sales in the market.
  The argument mistakes a condition required for a certain result to obtain, the belief of consumers, for a condition that by itself is sufficient to guarantee that result, actual market share.
  Therefore, the argument commits the error of mistaking a necessary condition for a sufficient condition.
  The answer is B: mistaking a condition required if a certain result is to obtain for a condition that by itself is sufficient to guarantee that result.

  The argument does not take evidence that a claim is believed to be true to constitute evidence that the claim is in fact true.
  The argument does not describe survey results that were obtained in the past as if they are bound to obtain in the future as well.

Topic: Law
Context: Science journalist: Brown dwarfs are celestial objects with more mass than planets but less mass than stars. They are identified by their mass and whether or not lithium is present in their atmospheres. Stars at least as massive as the Sun have lithium remaining in their atmospheres because the mixing of elements in their internal nuclear furnaces is incomplete. Stars with less mass than the Sun have no lithium because the element has been fully mixed into their nuclear furnaces and consumed. A brown dwarf does not have a fully functional nuclear furnace and so its lithium cannot be consumed.
Question: Which one of the following is most strongly supported by the science journalist's statements?
Choices:
  A: Any celestial object without lithium in its atmosphere is a star with less mass than the Sun.
  B: Any celestial object with lithium in its atmosphere has a nuclear furnace that has incompletely mixed the object's elements.
  C: No celestial object that has no lithium in its atmosphere is a brown dwarf.
  D: No celestial object with lithium in its atmosphere has less mass than the Sun.
  E: No celestial object less massive than a brown dwarf has lithium in its atmosphere.

### Temperature: 5.0 | Problem 59 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: A computer game publisher has recently released its latest adventure game. The game's inventive puzzles and compelling plot induce even casual players to become preoccupied with completing it. The game can be purchased from retail outlets or rented for two-day intervals. The publisher offers a rebate equal to the cost of one rental for renters who go on to purchase the game, saving them a significant portion of the purchase price. Since the rate of sales now meets expectations and rentals are exceeding expectations, the publisher predicts that soon sales of the game will also exceed expectations.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to justify the publisher's prediction?
Choices:
  A: The game can be purchased directly from the publisher as well as from retailers.
  B: It takes several weeks for most players to complete the game.
  C: The publisher's games are among the most popular computer games on the market.
  D: Most people who complete the game do not play it extensively afterward.
  E: Some people buy and complete the game and then give it away to a friend.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  A: The game can be purchased directly from the publisher as well as from retailers.
  B: It takes several weeks for most players to complete the game.
  C: The publisher's games are among the most popular computer games on the market.
  D: Most people who complete the game do not play it extensively afterward.
  E: Some people buy and complete the game and then give it away to a friend.
Thought: 
  The publisher predicts that soon sales of the game will also exceed expectations.
  To justify the prediction, we need to find an option that indicates that the game will continue to be in demand even after rentals are over.
  A: This option does not provide any information that can help to justify the publisher's prediction.
  B: This option indicates that the game takes several weeks for most players to complete it, which means that the game will continue to be in demand even after rentals are over.
  C: This option indicates that the publisher's games are popular, but it does not provide any information that can help to justify the publisher's prediction.
  D: This option indicates that most people who complete the game do not play it extensively afterward, which means that the game may not be in demand after rentals are over.
  E: This option indicates that some people buy and complete the game and then give it away to a friend, which means that the game may not be in demand after rentals are over.
  Therefore, the most helpful option to justify the publisher's prediction is B: It takes several weeks for most players to complete the game.
Criticism: 
  There is no criticism to this answer.

Choices:
  A: If the people who inhabited the valley for so long had been invaded, or iflbere had been a dramatic climatic change, there would have been chaoges in the valley's architecture. But architecture in the valley remained the same throughout their stay. Thus, the valley people must not have been invaded at any time during their stay.

  C: If the company had succeeded in selling its subsidiaries and used the cash to purchase the new patent, its stock price would have doubled in the last two years. But the price oflbe stock did not increase in that time. Thus, the company must have failed to sell its subsidiaries.
  D: City residents were expected to show a great deal of support for the rebels iflbe battle was won and the jailed rebel leaders freed. Residents have shown a great deal of support or the rebels for the last three days. Therefore, the rebels must have won the battle.
  E: Iflbe television station's new wealber forecasting equipment had been worth the investment, the accuracy of its forecasts would have risen, along wilb its ratings. But the station's ratings actually decreased. Thus, the new equipment is no improvement on the old.

Context: Government official: Residents who are foreign citizens can serve as public servants at most levels, but not as cabinet secretaries. Moreover, a cabinet undersecretary is expected to serve as cabinet secretary when the actual secretary is unavailable. So, ____.
Question: Which one of the following most logically completes the government official's statement?
Choices:
  A: foreign citizens who serve as public servants should be granted citizenship in the country they serve
  B: foreign citizens should not be appointed as cabinet undersecretaries
  C: only former cabinet undersecretaries should be appointed as cabinet secretaries

### Temperature: 5.0 | Problem 62 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Figorian Wildlife Commission: The development of wetlands in industrialized nations for residential and commercial uses has endangered many species. To protect wildlife we must regulate such development in Figoria: future wetland development must be offset by the construction of replacement wetland habitats. Thus, development would cause no net reduction of wetlands and pose no threat to the species that inhabit them. Figorian Development Commission: Other nations have flagrantly developed wetlands at the expense of wildlife. We have conserved. Since Figorian wetland development might not affect wildlife and is necessary for growth, we should allow development. We have as much right to govern our own resources as countries that have already put their natural resources to commercial use.
Question: Which one of the following principles, if accepted, would most strongly support the Figorian Development Commission's position against the Figorian Wildlife Commission's position?
Choices:
  A: National resources should be regulated by international agreement when wildlife is endangered.
  B: The right of future generations to have wildlife preserved supersedes the economic needs of individual nations.
  C: Only when a reduction of populations of endangered species by commercial development has been found should regulation be implemented to prevent further damage.
  D: Environment regulation must aim at preventing any further environmental damage and cannot allow for the different degrees to which different nations have already harmed the environment.
  E: It is imprudent to allow further depletion of natural resources.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The Figorian Wildlife Commission wants to regulate wetland development in Figoria to protect wildlife by offsetting development with the construction of replacement wetland habitats.
  The Figorian Development Commission thinks that Figorian wetland development might not affect wildlife and is necessary for growth, and that Figoria has as much right to govern its own resources as countries that have already put their natural resources to commercial use.
Thought: 
  The Figorian Development Commission's position is that Figoria has the right to develop its own resources and that wetland development might not affect wildlife. Therefore, the principle that would most strongly support their position is one that prioritizes a nation's right to govern its own resources over international regulation to protect wildlife.
  A: This principle supports international regulation of national resources when wildlife is endangered, which goes against the Figorian Development Commission's position.
  B: This principle prioritizes the preservation of wildlife over the economic needs of individual nations, which goes against the Figorian Development Commission's position.
  C: This principle suggests that regulation should only be implemented after damage has already been done, which is not relevant to the Figorian Development Commission's position.
  D: This principle suggests that environmental regulation must aim to prevent any further damage, which is not relevant to the Figorian Development Commission's position.
  E: This principle suggests that it is imprudent to allow further depletion of natural resources, which goes against the Figorian Development Commission's position.
  Therefore, none of the principles strongly supports the Figorian Development Commission's position.
Criticism: 
  While the Figorian Development Commission's position is that Figoria has the right to develop its own resources and that wetland development might not affect wildlife, this position does not necessarily have a principle that strongly supports it.
Action: Answer("None of the Above")

Topic: Law
Context: Columnist: Although most people favor the bill and the bill does not violate anyone's basic human rights, it will not be passed for many years, if at all; nor will any similar bill. Those people who would be adversely affected were it to become law are very influential. This shows that, if this country is a democracy at all, it is not a well-functioning one.
Question: Which one of the following principles, if valid, most helps to justify the columnist's reasoning?
Choices:
  A: In a well-functioning democracy, any bill that would benefit most people will be passed into law within a few years if it does not violate anyone's basic human rights.
  B: If a democracy is well functioning, then any bill that is opposed by influential people but favored by most other people will eventually pass into law.
  C: In a well-functioning democracy, a bill that is favored by most people will become law within a few years only if those who oppose it are not very influential.
  D: Any bill passed into law in a well-functioning democracy will be favored by most people and be consistent with individuals' basic human rights.
  E: A bill that most people favor will be passed promptly into law in a well-functioning democracy if the bill does not violate anyone's basic human rights.

  The columnist argues that a bill that most people favor and does not violate anyone's basic human rights will not be passed into law due to the opposition of influential people.

  B: This principle suggests that any bill that is opposed by influential people but favored by most other people will eventually pass into law in a well-functioning democracy, which is consistent with the columnist's argument.

  E: This principle suggests that a bill that most people favor will be passed promptly into law in a well-functioning democracy if the bill does not violate anyone's basic human rights, which is not consistent with the columnist's argument.

  Therefore, Principle B most helps to justify the columnist's reasoning.
  The answer is B: If a democracy is well functioning, then any bill that is opposed by influential people but favored by most other people will eventually pass into law.

### Temperature: 5.0 | Problem 64 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Editorial: The premier's economic advisor assures her that with the elimination of wasteful spending the goal of reducing taxes while not significantly decreasing government services can be met. But the premier should not listen to this advisor, who in his youth was convicted of embezzlement. Surely his economic advice is as untrustworthy as he is himself, and so the premier should discard any hope of reducing taxes without a significant decrease in government services.
Question: Which one of the following is a questionable argumentative strategy employed in the editorial's argument?
Choices:
  A: rejecting a proposal on the grounds that a particular implementation of the proposal is likely to fail
  B: trying to win support for a proposal by playing on people's fears of what could happen otherwise
  C: criticizing the source of a claim rather than examining the claim itself
  D: taking lack of evidence for a claim as evidence undermining that claim
  E: presupposing what it sets out to establish
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The editorial argues that the premier should not listen to her economic advisor because he was convicted of embezzlement in his youth.

  B: trying to win support for a proposal by playing on people's fears of what could happen otherwise is a questionable argumentative strategy.
  C: criticizing the source of a claim rather than examining the claim itself is a questionable argumentative strategy.
  D: taking lack of evidence for a claim as evidence undermining that claim is a questionable argumentative strategy.
  E: presupposing what it sets out to establish is a questionable argumentative strategy.
Thought:
  The editorial argues that the premier should not listen to her economic advisor because he was convicted of embezzlement in his youth.
  This is a form of criticizing the source of a claim rather than examining the claim itself.
  Therefore, the questionable argumentative strategy employed in the editorial's argument is C: criticizing the source of a claim rather than examining the claim itself.

Topic: Law
Context: Biologist: Humans have five fingers because we descended from a fish with five phalanges in its fins. Despite our prejudices to the contrary, our configuration of fingers is no more or less useful than several other possible configurations, e.g., six per hand. So, if humans had descended from a fish with six phalanges in its fins and had six fingers on each hand, then we would be just as content with that configuration.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most strengthens the biologist's argument?
Choices:
  A: Everyone is equally content with our present configuration of fingers.
  B: Humans are never equally content with two things of unequal usefulness.
  C: Humans are always equally content with two things of equal usefulness.
  D: The perceived usefulness of our configuration of fingers is an illusory result of our prejudices.
  E: At least one species of fish had six phalanges in its fins.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  The biologist argues that the number of fingers humans have is not necessarily the best or only useful configuration. 
  A: This choice is irrelevant to the argument.
  B: This choice contradicts the argument, and therefore weakens it.
  C: This choice is irrelevant to the argument.
  D: This choice supports the argument, but it does not directly strengthen it.
  E: This choice supports the argument that other fish species have different configurations of phalanges in their fins.

  The biologist argues that humans would be just as content with six fingers if we had descended from a fish with six phalanges in its fins. 
  If there is a species of fish that has six phalanges in its fins, then it is possible that humans could have evolved to have six fingers.
  Therefore, the biologist's argument is strengthened if E is true.

### Temperature: 5.0 | Problem 66 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Dried parsley should never be used in cooking, for it is far less tasty and healthful than fresh parsley is.
Question: Which one of the following principles, if valid, most clearly helps to justify the argument above?
Choices:
  A: Fresh ingredients should be used in cooking whenever possible.
  B: Only the tastiest ingredients should ever be used in cooking.
  C: Ingredients that should never be used in cooking are generally neither tasty nor healthful.
  D: Parsley that is not both tasty and healthful should never be used in cooking.
  E: In cooking, dried ingredients are inferior to fresh ingredients.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
- The argument claims that dried parsley should never be used in cooking.
- The argument gives two reasons for this: dried parsley is less tasty and less healthful than fresh parsley.
Choices:
- A: This principle supports the argument, but it is too broad. The argument only concerns parsley, not all ingredients.
- B: This principle is too extreme. The argument does not claim that only the tastiest ingredients should be used.
- C: This principle is too broad. The argument only concerns dried parsley, not all ingredients that should never be used in cooking.
- D: This principle is too specific. The argument does not claim that parsley that is not both tasty and healthful should never be used.
- E: This principle supports the argument. The argument claims that dried parsley is less tasty and less healthful than fresh parsley, so it implies that dried ingredients are generally inferior to fresh ingredients.
Thought:
- The argument claims that dried parsley should never be used in cooking because it is less tasty and less healthful than fresh parsley.
- The principle that supports this argument is that dried ingredients are generally inferior to fresh ingredients.
- Choice E expresses this principle.
- Therefore, the answer is E.
Criticism:
- None.
Action: Answer("E")

Topic: Law
Context: Detective: Because the embezzler must have had specialized knowledge and access to internal financial records, we can presume that the embezzler worked for XYZ Corporation as either an accountant or an actuary. But an accountant would probably not make the kind of mistakes in ledger entries that led to the discovery of the embezzlement. Thus it is likely that the embezzler is one of the actuaries.
Question: Each of the following weakens the detective's argument EXCEPT:
Choices:
  A: The actuaries' activities while working for XYZ Corporation were more closely scrutinized by supervisors than were the activities of the accountants.
  B: There is evidence of breaches in computer security at the time of the embezzlement that could have given persons outside XYZ Corporation access to internal financial records.
  C: XYZ Corporation employs eight accountants, whereas it has only two actuaries on its staff.
  D: An independent report released before the crime took place concluded that XYZ Corporation was vulnerable to embezzlement.
  E: Certain security measures at XYZ Corporation made it more difficult for the actuaries to have access to internal financial records than for the accountants.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The detective presumes that the embezzler worked for XYZ Corporation as either an accountant or an actuary.
  The detective argues that it is likely that the embezzler is one of the actuaries because an accountant would probably not make the kind of mistakes in ledger entries that led to the discovery of the embezzlement.
Thought:

  B: If there is evidence of breaches in computer security at the time of the embezzlement that could have given persons outside XYZ Corporation access to internal financial records, then it is possible that the embezzler was not an employee of XYZ Corporation. This weakens the detective's argument.
  C: The fact that XYZ Corporation employs eight accountants, whereas it has only two actuaries on its staff, does not necessarily weaken or strengthen the detective's argument. It is irrelevant to the argument.
  D: The fact that an independent report released before the crime took place concluded that XYZ Corporation was vulnerable to embezzlement does not necessarily weaken or strengthen the detective's argument. It is irrelevant to the argument.

### Temperature: 5.0 | Problem 68 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: One should not play a practical joke on someone if it shows contempt for that person or if one believes it might bring significant harm to that person.
Question: The principle stated above, if valid, most helps to justify the reasoning in which one of the following arguments?
Choices:
  A: I should not have played that practical joke on you yesterday. Even if it was not contemptuous, I should have realized that it would bring significant harm to someone.
  B: I have no reason to think that the practical joke I want to play would harm anyone. So, since the joke would show no contempt for the person the joke is played on, it would not be wrong for me to play it.
  C: Because of the circumstances, it would be wrong for me to play the practical joke I had intended to play on you. Even though it would not show contempt for anyone, it could easily bring you significant harm.
  D: It would have been wrong for me to play the practical joke that I had intended to play on you. Even though I did not have reason to think that it would significantly harm anyone, I did think that it would show contempt for someone.
  E: Someone was harmed as a result of my practical joke. Thus, even though it did not show contempt for the person I played the joke on, I should not have played it.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The principle stated above is that one should not play a practical joke on someone if it shows contempt for that person or if one believes it might bring significant harm to that person.
Thought: 
  The principle suggests that playing a practical joke is wrong if it shows contempt for that person or if one believes it might bring significant harm to that person.
  Choice A acknowledges that playing a practical joke that could bring significant harm is wrong, which aligns with the principle.
  Choice B assumes that the joke would not bring significant harm and would not show contempt, so it does not address the principle.
  Choice C acknowledges that playing a practical joke that could bring significant harm is wrong, which aligns with the principle, even if it does not show contempt.
  Choice D acknowledges that showing contempt for someone is wrong, which aligns with the principle, but does not mention significant harm.
  Choice E acknowledges that playing a practical joke that harms someone is wrong, which aligns with the principle, but does not mention contempt.
  Only Choice A aligns with the principle stated in the question.
Action: Answer("A")

### Temperature: 5.0 | Problem 69 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: A film makes a profit if the number of people who see it is sufficient to generate revenues from ticket sales greater than the amount spent to make it. Hence, the primary goal of movie executives is to maximize the number of people who see a film. However, it is not the primary goal of television executives to maximize the number of viewers for their shows.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most helps to explain the difference between the goals of movie executives and those of television executives?
Choices:
  A: More people are willing to see a film more than once than are willing to watch a television show more than once.
  B: There is no analog in television to the large profits that owners of movie theaters make by selling refreshments to their customers.
  C: The average cost of producing an hour of film is much greater than the average cost of producing an hour of television.
  D: Television shows make their profits from sponsors, who are chiefly concerned with the purchasing power of the people who watch a television show.
  E: Over half of the most popular television shows are shows that viewers do not have to pay to watch.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  The primary goal of movie executives is to maximize the number of people who see a film as this generates revenue from ticket sales.
  The primary goal of television executives is not to maximize the number of viewers for their shows.
Choices:
  A: This option highlights a difference between films and television shows, but it does not help explain why the goals of movie executives and television executives differ.
  B: This option highlights a difference between the two industries, but it does not help explain why the goals of movie executives and television executives differ.
  C: This option highlights a difference between the two industries, but it does not help explain why the goals of movie executives and television executives differ.
  D: This option provides a possible explanation for why television executives are not primarily concerned with maximizing the number of viewers for their shows. If the profits of television shows come from sponsors who want to reach a specific audience, then television executives will be more concerned with appealing to that audience than with maximizing the number of viewers.
  E: This option highlights a difference between films and television shows, but it does not help explain why the goals of movie executives and television executives differ.
Thought:
  The primary goal of movie executives is to maximize the number of people who see a film.
  The primary goal of television executives is not to maximize the number of viewers for their shows.
  Option D provides a possible explanation for why this is the case, as television executives are more concerned with appealing to a specific audience than with maximizing the number of viewers.
  Therefore, the answer is D.
Criticism:
  None.
Action: Answer("D")

This implies that television executives are interested in attracting a specific audience to their shows. Hence, the primary goal of television executives is not to maximize the number of viewers for their shows, but rather to attract viewers with a high purchasing power.
  Option E does not explain the difference between the goals of movie executives and those of television executives.

    This statement is irrelevant to the difference in goals between movie and television executives.
  C: The average cost of producing an hour of film is much greater than the average cost of producing an hour of television.
    This statement helps explain the difference in goals between movie and television executives. Since films are more expensive to produce than television shows, movie executives need to maximize the number of people who see a film to generate revenue from ticket sales to recoup their expenses. On the other hand, television executives have lower production costs per hour of programming, so they do not need to maximize the number of viewers to generate revenue.

  The primary goal of television executives is not to maximize the number of viewers for their shows.
  The cost of producing a film is much greater than the cost of producing an hour of television.
  Therefore, the difference in goals between movie and television executives can be explained by the higher production costs of films.
  The answer is C: The average cost of producing an hour of film is much greater than the average cost of producing an hour of television.

### Temperature: 5.0 | Problem 70 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Curator: Our museum displays only twentieth-century works, which are either on loan from private collectors or in the museum's permanent collection. Prints of all of the latter works are available in the museum store. The museum store also sells prints of some works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection, such as Hopper's Nighthawks.
Question: If the curator's statements are true, which one of the following must be true?
Choices:
  A: Every print in the museum store is of a work that is either on loan to the museum from a private collector or part of the museum's permanent collection.
  B: Every print that is sold in the museum store is a copy of a twentieth-century work.
  C: There are prints in the museum store of every work that is displayed in the museum and not on loan from a private collector.
  D: Hopper's Nighthawks is both a twentieth-century work and a work on loan to the museum from a private collector.
  E: Hopper's Nighthawks is not displayed in the museum.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
- The museum displays only twentieth-century works.
- These works are either on loan from private collectors or in the museum's permanent collection.
- Prints of all of the latter works are available in the museum store.
- The museum store also sells prints of some works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection, such as Hopper's Nighthawks.

Thought:
- Every print in the museum store is either of a work that is on loan to the museum from a private collector or is part of the museum's permanent collection.
- Prints of all works in the museum's permanent collection are available in the museum store.
- Some prints sold in the museum store are of works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection.
- Hopper's Nighthawks is not part of the museum's permanent collection but is sold in the museum store.
- Therefore, not every print sold in the museum store is of a work that is either on loan to the museum from a private collector or part of the museum's permanent collection.

Criticism:
- There is no information to support the claim that every print that is sold in the museum store is a copy of a twentieth-century work.
- There is no information to support the claim that there are prints in the museum store of every work that is displayed in the museum and not on loan from a private collector.
- There is no information to support the claim that Hopper's Nighthawks is on loan to the museum from a private collector.

Action: Answer("A")
Response 1:
Knowledge: 
  The museum displays only twentieth-century works.
  The museum displays works that are either on loan from private collectors or in the museum's permanent collection.
  Prints of all of the museum's permanent collection works are available in the museum store.
  The museum store also sells prints of some works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection, such as Hopper's Nighthawks.
Thought: 
  The museum displays only twentieth-century works, which are either on loan from private collectors or in the museum's permanent collection.
  Prints of all of the museum's permanent collection works are available in the museum store.
  The museum store also sells prints of some works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection, such as Hopper's Nighthawks.
  Therefore, every print in the museum store is not of a work that is either on loan to the museum from a private collector or part of the museum's permanent collection. 
  Choice A is false.
  Every print that is sold in the museum store is not necessarily a copy of a twentieth-century work, because the museum store also sells prints of some works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection, such as Hopper's Nighthawks. 
  Choice B is false.
  There are prints in the museum store of every work that is displayed in the museum and not on loan from a private collector is not necessarily true, because the museum store also sells prints of some works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection, such as Hopper's Nighthawks.
  Choice C is false.
  Hopper's Nighthawks is not part of the museum's permanent collection, so it cannot be a work on loan to the museum from a private collector. 
  Choice D is false.
  Hopper's Nighthawks is not part of the museum's permanent collection, and it is not stated whether it is displayed in the museum or not. 
  Choice E is uncertain.
Criticism: 
  Your reasoning is correct.
Action: Answer("B")
Response 2:
Knowledge: 
  The museum displays only twentieth-century works.
  The works displayed are either on loan from private collectors or in the museum's permanent collection.
  Prints of all of the museum's permanent collection works are available in the museum store.
  The museum store also sells prints of some works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection, such as Hopper's Nighthawks.
Thought: 
  Choice A is incorrect because the museum store sells prints of some works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection.
  Choice B is incorrect because the curator's statements do not imply that every print sold in the museum store is a copy of a twentieth-century work.
  Choice C is incorrect because the curator's statements do not imply that prints of every work displayed in the museum and not on loan from a private collector are available in the museum store.
  Choice D is incorrect because the curator's statements do not imply that Hopper's Nighthawks is on loan to the museum from a private collector.
  Choice E is correct because the curator's statements do not provide information about whether Hopper's Nighthawks is displayed in the museum.
Action: Answer("E")
Response 3:

- The museum displays only twentieth-century works.

- Prints of all of the museum's permanent collection works are available in the museum store.
- The museum store also sells prints of some works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection, such as Hopper's Nighthawks.
Thought:
- Every print in the museum store is either a print of a work on loan from a private collector or a print of a work in the museum's permanent collection.
- Every work in the museum is either on loan from a private collector or in the museum's permanent collection.
- Therefore, every print in the museum store is either a print of a work in the museum or a print of a work on loan to the museum from a private collector.
- Every work in the museum is a twentieth-century work.
- Therefore, every print in the museum store is a print of a twentieth-century work.
- Hopper's Nighthawks is not part of the museum's permanent collection.
- Therefore, Hopper's Nighthawks is a work that is on loan to the museum from a private collector.
- Hopper's Nighthawks is not displayed in the museum.
Criticism:
- The conclusion that every print in the museum store is a print of a twentieth-century work is based on the assumption that every work in the museum is a twentieth-century work, which is not explicitly stated in the given information.
- The statement that every work in the museum is either on loan from a private collector or in the museum's permanent collection does not necessarily mean that every work on loan is not part of the museum's permanent collection.

Response 8:
Knowledge: 
  - The museum displays only twentieth-century works.
  - The works displayed are either on loan from private collectors or in the museum's permanent collection.
  - Prints of all of the latter works are available in the museum store.
  - The museum store also sells prints of some works that are not part of the museum's permanent collection, such as Hopper's Nighthawks.
  
Thought:
  - Every print in the museum store is either of a work on loan to the museum from a private collector or part of the museum's permanent collection because those are the only works displayed in the museum.
  - Every print that is sold in the museum store is a copy of a twentieth-century work because the museum only displays twentieth-century works.
  - There are prints in the museum store of every work that is displayed in the museum and not on loan from a private collector because prints of all of the latter works are available in the museum store.
  - Hopper's Nighthawks is not on loan from a private collector, so it must not be part of the museum's permanent collection.
  - It is not stated whether Hopper's Nighthawks is displayed in the museum or not.
  
Criticism:
  - The statement "Every print in the museum store is either of a work on loan to the museum from a private collector or part of the museum's permanent collection because those are the only works displayed in the museum" is not necessarily true. The museum store could sell prints of works that are not on display in the museum.
  - The statement "Every print that is sold in the museum store is a copy of a twentieth-century work because the museum only displays twentieth-century works" is not necessarily true. The museum store could sell prints of works from other time periods.
  - The statement "There are prints in the museum store of every work that is displayed in the museum and not on loan from a private collector because prints of all of the latter works are available in the museum store" is not necessarily true. The museum store could choose not to sell prints of some works that are on display in the museum.
  - The statement "Hopper's Nighthawks is not on loan from a private collector, so it must not be part of the museum's permanent collection" is not necessarily true. Hopper's Nighthawks could be a work that is on loan to the museum from a private collector and also not part of the museum's permanent collection.
  
Action: Answer("B")

### Temperature: 5.0 | Problem 71 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: A person who knowingly brings about misfortune should be blamed for it. However, in some cases a person who unwittingly brings about misfortune should not be blamed for it. For example, a person should never be blamed for unwittingly bringing about misfortune if the person could not reasonably have foreseen it.
Question: The principles above, if valid, most help to justify the reasoning in which one of the following?
Choices:
  A: Although he would have realized it if he had thought about it, it did not occur to Riley that parking his car in the center lane of Main Street could lead to a traffic accident. So, if a traffic accident does result from Riley's parking his car in the center lane of Main Street, he should not be blamed for it.
  B: Oblicek had no idea that suggesting to her brother that he take out a loan to expand his business was likely to cause the business to go bankrupt, nor could she have reasonably foreseen this. So, if the loan does cause her brother's business to go bankrupt, Oblicek should not be blamed for it.
  C: Gougon had no reason to think that serving the hollandaise sauce would make his guests ill, but he was concerned that it might. Thus, if the hollandaise sauce does make Gougon's guests ill, Gougon should be blamed for it.
  D: When Dr. Fitzpatrick gave his patient the wrong medicine, he did not know that it would cause the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure. So, if no one else knowingly did anything that contributed to the patient's increase in blood pressure, no one other than Dr. Fitzpatrick is to blame for it.
  E: Any reasonable person could have foreseen that dropping a lit cigarette in dry leaves would start a fire. Thus, even if Kapp did not realize this, she is to blame for starting a fire on Rodriguez's farm since she dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves there.
Response 0:
Knowledge: 
  The passage states that a person who unwittingly brings about misfortune should not be blamed for it if the person could not reasonably have foreseen it.
Thought: 
  Option A: Riley parked his car in the center lane of Main Street and did not realize that it could lead to a traffic accident. If a traffic accident does result from Riley's parking, he should not be blamed for it. This aligns with the principle stated in the passage. 
  Option B: Oblicek suggested to her brother to take out a loan to expand his business and had no idea that it would cause the business to go bankrupt. If the loan does cause the business to go bankrupt, Oblicek should not be blamed for it. This also aligns with the principle stated in the passage.
  Option C: Gougon served hollandaise sauce to his guests and had no reason to think that it would make them ill. However, he was concerned that it might. If the hollandaise sauce does make Gougon's guests ill, Gougon should be blamed for it. This contradicts the principle stated in the passage since Gougon did not unwittingly bring about the misfortune.
  Option D: Dr. Fitzpatrick gave his patient the wrong medicine and did not know that it would cause the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure. No one else knowingly did anything that contributed to the patient's increase in blood pressure. This aligns with the principle stated in the passage.
  Option E: Kapp dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves on Rodriguez's farm and did not realize that it would start a fire. However, any reasonable person could have foreseen that dropping a lit cigarette in dry leaves would start a fire. Thus, Kapp should be blamed for starting the fire. This contradicts the principle stated in the passage since Kapp could have reasonably foreseen the misfortune.
Conclusion: 
  Options A, B, and D align with the principle stated in the passage. Options C and E contradict the principle stated in the passage.
Action: Answer("B")

Thought: 
  The principle states that a person who unwittingly brings about misfortune should not be blamed for it if the person could not reasonably have foreseen it.
  A: Riley did not think that parking his car in the center lane of Main Street could lead to a traffic accident. If a traffic accident results from Riley's parking his car in the center lane of Main Street, he should not be blamed for it.
  B: Oblicek had no idea that suggesting to her brother that he take out a loan to expand his business was likely to cause the business to go bankrupt, nor could she have reasonably foreseen this. If the loan does cause her brother's business to go bankrupt, Oblicek should not be blamed for it.
  C: Gougon had no reason to think that serving the hollandaise sauce would make his guests ill, but he was concerned that it might. If the hollandaise sauce does make Gougon's guests ill, Gougon should be blamed for it.
  D: Dr. Fitzpatrick gave his patient the wrong medicine and did not know that it would cause the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure. If no one else knowingly did anything that contributed to the patient's increase in blood pressure, no one other than Dr. Fitzpatrick is to blame for it.
  E: Kapp dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves and started a fire on Rodriguez's farm. Any reasonable person could have foreseen that dropping a lit cigarette in dry leaves would start a fire. Kapp is to blame for starting a fire on Rodriguez's farm.
Criticism: 
  The principle states that a person who unwittingly brings about misfortune should not be blamed for it if the person could not reasonably have foreseen it. 
  A, B, and D all involve situations where the person could not have reasonably foreseen the misfortune. 
  C involves a person who had no reason to think that serving the hollandaise sauce would make his guests ill, but was concerned that it might. This option does not fit the principle because the person was concerned that the hollandaise sauce might make his guests ill, meaning that it was reasonable to foresee the misfortune.
  E involves a person who dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves and started a fire on Rodriguez's farm. Any reasonable person could have foreseen that dropping a lit cigarette in dry leaves would start a fire. This option also does not fit the principle because it was reasonable to foresee the misfortune.

If no one else knowingly did anything that contributed to the patient's increase in blood pressure, no one other than Dr. Fitzpatrick is to blame for it.

Thought: 
  A: Riley parked his car in the center lane of Main Street and did not think it could lead to a traffic accident. If a traffic accident does result from Riley's parking his car in the center lane of Main Street, he should not be blamed for it.
  Riley did not knowingly bring about the misfortune of a traffic accident, but he should have reasonably foreseen that parking his car in the center lane of Main Street could lead to a traffic accident. Therefore, Riley should be blamed for the traffic accident.
  B: Oblicek suggested to her brother that he take out a loan to expand his business but had no idea it was likely to cause the business to go bankrupt. If the loan does cause her brother's business to go bankrupt, Oblicek should not be blamed for it.
  Oblicek did not knowingly bring about the misfortune of her brother's business going bankrupt, and she could not have reasonably foreseen that suggesting he take out a loan to expand his business would cause it to go bankrupt. Therefore, Oblicek should not be blamed for her brother's business going bankrupt.
  C: Gougon served hollandaise sauce without reason to think it would make his guests ill. If the hollandaise sauce does make Gougon's guests ill, Gougon should be blamed for it.
  Gougon did not knowingly bring about the misfortune of his guests becoming ill from the hollandaise sauce. However, he should have reasonably foreseen that serving food could make his guests ill if he did not take proper precautions. Therefore, Gougon should be blamed for his guests becoming ill from the hollandaise sauce.
  D: Dr. Fitzpatrick gave his patient the wrong medicine and did not know it would cause the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure. If no one else knowingly did anything that contributed to the patient's increase in blood pressure, no one other than Dr. Fitzpatrick is to blame for it.
  Dr. Fitzpatrick did not knowingly bring about the misfortune of the patient experiencing greatly increased blood pressure. However, he should have reasonably foreseen that giving the wrong medicine could cause harm to the patient. Therefore, Dr. Fitzpatrick should be blamed for the patient's increase in blood pressure.
  E: Kapp dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves on Rodriguez's farm. Any reasonable person could have foreseen that dropping a lit cigarette in dry leaves would start a fire. Even if Kapp did not realize this, she is to blame for starting a fire on Rodriguez's farm.
  Kapp unwittingly brought about the misfortune of starting a fire on Rodriguez's farm by dropping a lit cigarette in dry leaves. However, any reasonable person could have foreseen that dropping a lit cigarette in dry leaves would start a fire. Therefore, Kapp should be blamed for starting the fire on Rodriguez's farm.
Conclusion: 
  The principles state that a person who unwittingly brings about misfortune should not be blamed for it if the person could not reasonably have foreseen it. Therefore, the reasoning that is most justified by these principles is B: Oblicek had no idea that suggesting to her brother that he take out a loan to expand his business was likely to cause the business to go bankrupt, nor could she have reasonably foreseen this. So, if the loan does cause her brother's business to go bankrupt, Oblicek should not be blamed for it. 
Action: Answer("B")

  Riley did not realize that parking his car in the center lane of Main Street could lead to a traffic accident.

Response 8:
Knowledge: 
  The principles state that a person who knowingly brings about misfortune should be blamed for it, but a person who unwittingly brings about misfortune should not be blamed for it if the person could not reasonably have foreseen it.
  A: Riley parked his car in the center lane of Main Street without realizing that it could lead to a traffic accident. 
  B: Oblicek suggested to her brother that he take out a loan to expand his business without knowing that it was likely to cause the business to go bankrupt.
  C: Gougon served hollandaise sauce to his guests without knowing that it would make them ill.
  D: Dr. Fitzpatrick gave his patient the wrong medicine without knowing that it would cause the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure.
  E: Kapp dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves on Rodriguez's farm without realizing that it would start a fire.
Thought: 
  Option A: Riley parked his car in the center lane of Main Street without realizing that it could lead to a traffic accident. Since he could not have foreseen this, he should not be blamed for it. This aligns with the principles stated above.
  Option B: Oblicek suggested to her brother that he take out a loan to expand his business without knowing that it was likely to cause the business to go bankrupt. Since she could not have foreseen this, she should not be blamed for it. This aligns with the principles stated above.
  Option C: Gougon served hollandaise sauce to his guests without knowing that it would make them ill. Although he was concerned that it might, he had no reason to think that it would. Therefore, he should not be blamed for it. This aligns with the principles stated above.
  Option D: Dr. Fitzpatrick gave his patient the wrong medicine without knowing that it would cause the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure. Since he could not have foreseen this, he should not be blamed for it. This aligns with the principles stated above.
  Option E: Kapp dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves on Rodriguez's farm without realizing that it would start a fire. However, any reasonable person could have foreseen that dropping a lit cigarette in dry leaves would start a fire. Therefore, Kapp should be blamed for it. This does not align with the principles stated above.
Conclusion: 
  Options A, B, and D align with the principles stated above, but options C and E do not. 
  The best answer is either A, B, or D, but since option A and option B both align with the principles more closely than option D, the answer is A: Although he would have realized it if he had thought about it, it did not occur to Riley that parking his car in the center lane of Main Street could lead to a traffic accident. So, if a traffic accident does result from Riley's parking his car in the center lane of Main Street, he should not be blamed for it.
Response 9:
Knowledge: 
  The principles state that a person who knowingly brings about misfortune should be blamed for it. However, in some cases, a person who unwittingly brings about misfortune should not be blamed for it if the person could not reasonably have foreseen it.
Thought:
  A: Riley parked his car in the center lane of Main Street, which could lead to a traffic accident. Although he did not realize it, he could have foreseen it. Therefore, he should be blamed for any traffic accident that results from his parking.
  B: Oblicek suggested to her brother to take out a loan to expand his business, which caused the business to go bankrupt. She had no idea that this would happen, nor could she have foreseen it. Therefore, she should not be blamed for her brother's business going bankrupt.
  C: Gougon served hollandaise sauce to his guests, which made them ill. He had no reason to think that serving hollandaise sauce would make his guests ill. However, he was concerned that it might. Therefore, he should be blamed for making his guests ill.
  D: Dr. Fitzpatrick gave his patient the wrong medicine, which caused the patient to experience greatly increased blood pressure. He did not know that it would cause this, and no one else knowingly did anything that contributed to the patient's increase in blood pressure. Therefore, only Dr. Fitzpatrick should be blamed for it.
  E: Kapp dropped a lit cigarette in dry leaves on Rodriguez's farm, which started a fire. Any reasonable person could have foreseen that dropping a lit cigarette in dry leaves would start a fire. Therefore, Kapp should be blamed for starting the fire.
  The principles in the question state that a person who unwittingly brings about misfortune should not be blamed for it if the person could not reasonably have foreseen it. 
  Therefore, the reasoning in B is justified by the principles.
Action: Answer("B")
Votes: B, B, B, A, B, A, B, A, [None], B
Agent Answer: B
Correct Answer: B

### Temperature: 5.0 | Problem 72 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: People who have specialized knowledge about a scientific or technical issue are systematically excluded from juries for trials where that issue is relevant. Thus, trial by jury is not a fair means of settling disputes involving such issues.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
Choices:
  A: The more complicated the issue being litigated, the less likely it is that a juror without specialized knowledge of the field involved will be able to comprehend the testimony being given.
  B: The more a juror knows about a particular scientific or technical issue involved in a trial, the more likely it is that the juror will be prejudiced in favor of one of the litigating parties before the trial begins.
  C: Appointing an impartial arbitrator is not a fair means of settling disputes involving scientific or technical issues, because arbitrators tend to favor settlements in which both parties compromise on the issues.
  D: Experts who give testimony on scientific or technical issues tend to hedge their conclusions by discussing the possibility of error.
  E: Expert witnesses in specialized fields often command fees that are so high that many people involved in litigation cannot afford their services.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  The argument is that jurors without specialized knowledge cannot fairly settle disputes involving scientific or technical issues.
  A: The more complicated the issue, the less likely a juror without specialized knowledge can comprehend the testimony.
  B: Jurors with specialized knowledge may be prejudiced in favor of one party.
  C: Impartial arbitrators are not a fair means of settling disputes and tend to favor compromise.
  D: Expert witnesses may hedge their conclusions.
  E: Expert witnesses can be expensive.
Thought:
  The argument is that jurors without specialized knowledge cannot fairly settle disputes involving scientific or technical issues.
  Choice A strengthens the argument by saying that jurors cannot comprehend complicated issues.
  Choice B also strengthens the argument by saying that jurors with specialized knowledge may be biased.
  Choice C is irrelevant as it discusses impartial arbitrators, not jurors.
  Choice D is also irrelevant as it discusses expert witnesses, not jurors.
  Choice E weakens the argument by saying that expert witnesses are expensive, which implies that not all people involved in litigation can afford their services. Therefore, the argument that jurors are systematically excluded is weakened because it is possible that not all cases involving scientific or technical issues can afford expert witnesses.
  Therefore, the answer is E: Expert witnesses in specialized fields often command fees that are so high that many people involved in litigation cannot afford their services.
Criticism:
  There is no apparent flaw in the logic used to arrive at the answer.

### Temperature: 5.0 | Problem 73 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Richard: Because it fails to meet the fundamental requirement of art—that it represent—abstract art will eventually be seen as an aberration. Jung-Su: Although artists, like musicians, may reject literal representation, makers of abstract art choose to represent the purely formal features of objects, which are discovered only when everyday perspectives are rejected. Thus, whatever others might come to say, abstract art is part of the artistic mainstream.
Question: Richard and Jung-Su disagree over whether
Choices:
  A: makers of abstract art reject literal representation
  B: the fundamental requirement of art is that it represent
  C: musicians may reject literal representation
  D: abstract art will be seen as an aberration
  E: abstract art is representational
Response 0:

### Temperature: 5.0 | Problem 74 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Geologist: The dominant view that petroleum formed from the fossilized remains of plants and animals deep in the earth's crust has been challenged by scientists who hold that it formed, not from living material, but from deep carbon deposits dating from the formation of the earth. But their theory is refuted by the presence in petroleum of biomarkers, molecules indicating the past or present existence of a living organism.
Question: Which one of the following, if true, most weakens the geologist's argument?
Choices:
  A: Fossils have been discovered that are devoid of biomarkers.
  B: Living organisms only emerged long after the earth's formation.
  C: It would take many millions of years for organisms to become petroleum.
  D: Certain strains of bacteria thrive deep inside the earth's crust.
  E: Some carbon deposits were formed from the fossilized remains of plants.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  The geologist argues that petroleum formed from the fossilized remains of plants and animals.
  Scientists who hold that it formed from deep carbon deposits dating from the formation of the earth.
  The geologist's argument is refuted by the presence in petroleum of biomarkers.
Thought:
  The geologist's argument is that petroleum formed from the fossilized remains of plants and animals.
  Scientists challenge this view and argue that it formed from deep carbon deposits dating from the formation of the earth.
  The geologist's argument is refuted by the presence of biomarkers in petroleum.
  To weaken the geologist's argument, we need to show that the presence of biomarkers in petroleum does not necessarily indicate that petroleum formed from the fossilized remains of plants and animals.
  Option A is irrelevant to the argument.
  Option B is also irrelevant to the argument.
  Option C supports the geologist's argument and does not weaken it.
  Option D is also irrelevant to the argument.
  Option E weakens the argument by suggesting that some carbon deposits were formed from the fossilized remains of plants.
Action: Answer("E")
Response 1:
Knowledge:
  The geologist argues that petroleum is formed from the fossilized remains of plants and animals.
  Some scientists argue that petroleum is formed from deep carbon deposits dating from the formation of the earth.
  The geologist's argument is supported by the presence of biomarkers in petroleum.
Thought:
  The geologist argues that petroleum is formed from the fossilized remains of plants and animals.
  Some scientists argue that petroleum is formed from deep carbon deposits dating from the formation of the earth.
  The geologist's argument is supported by the presence of biomarkers in petroleum.
  To weaken the geologist's argument, we need to find an option that suggests that petroleum can be formed from sources other than living organisms.
  Option A suggests that fossils can exist without biomarkers, but it does not provide evidence that petroleum can be formed from sources other than living organisms.
  Option B suggests that living organisms only emerged long after the earth's formation, but it does not provide evidence that petroleum can be formed from sources other than living organisms.

### Temperature: 5.0 | Problem 75 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: City leader: If our city adopts the new tourism plan, the amount of money that tourists spend here annually will increase by at least $2 billion, creating as many jobs as a new automobile manufacturing plant would. It would be reasonable for the city to spend the amount of money necessary to convince an automobile manufacturer to build a plant here, but adopting the tourism plan would cost less.
Question: The city leader's statements, if true, provide the most support for which one of the following
Choices:
  A: The city should implement the least expensive job creation measures available.
  B: In general, it is reasonable for the city to spend money to try to convince manufacturing companies to build plants in the city.
  C: The city cannot afford both to spend money to convince an automobile manufacturer to build a plant in the city and to adopt the new tourism plan.
  D: It would be reasonable for the city to adopt the new tourism plan.
  E: The only way the city can create jobs is by increasing tourism.
Response 0:
Knowledge: The city leader believes that adopting the new tourism plan will increase the amount of money that tourists spend in the city by at least $2 billion, creating as many jobs as a new automobile manufacturing plant would. The leader also believes that adopting the tourism plan would cost less than convincing an automobile manufacturer to build a plant in the city.
Thought: The city leader's statements suggest that the new tourism plan is a cost-effective way to create jobs, as it would generate as much economic activity as a new automobile plant but at a lower cost. Therefore, the city should adopt the new tourism plan.
Criticism: The city leader's statements do not provide any evidence that the new tourism plan is the only or the best way to create jobs in the city. Additionally, the leader's comparison of the tourism plan to an automobile manufacturing plant may not be valid, as the two industries have different economic impacts and require different types of investment.
Action: Answer("D")

### Temperature: 5.0 | Problem 76 of 100 ###
Topic: Law
Context: Student: If a person has an immunity to infection by a microorganism, then that microorganism does not cause them to develop harmful symptoms. Since many people are exposed to staphylococcus without developing any harmful symptoms, it follows that they have an immunity to infection by this microorganism.
Question: The student's argument is most similar in its flawed pattern of reasoning to which one of the following?
Choices:
  A: Everything morally right is just, but some actions that best serve the interests of everyone are not just. Thus, some morally right actions do not serve the interests of everyone.
  B: Advertisers try to persuade people that certain claims are true. Since writers of fiction are not advertisers, they probably never try to persuade people that certain claims are true.
  C: Isabel said that she would take the medication. Obviously, though, she did not do so, because medication either cures disease or alleviates its symptoms, and Isabel is still quite ill.
  D: When business owners are subjected to excessive taxation, they become less willing to expand their businesses. The recent decline in business expansions thus shows that their taxes are too high.
  E: Studies show that doctors tend to wash their hands less often than any other health care professionals. This shows that the procedure cannot be of much value in preventing disease.
Response 0:
Knowledge:
  The student argues that if a person does not develop harmful symptoms after being exposed to a microorganism, then that person has an immunity to infection by that microorganism.
  The student also argues that many people are exposed to staphylococcus without developing any harmful symptoms.
Thought:
  The student's argument is flawed because it assumes that the absence of harmful symptoms is equivalent to immunity to infection. 
  The fact that many people are exposed to staphylococcus without developing harmful symptoms does not necessarily mean that they have an immunity to infection by that microorganism.
  Therefore, the student's argument is similar to the flawed pattern of reasoning in option C.
Criticism:
  The student's argument is not similar to the flawed pattern of reasoning in option A, B, D, or E.
  Option A is about the relationship between morality and serving the interests of everyone.
  Option B is about the persuasive intent of advertisers and writers of fiction.
  Option D is about the relationship between taxation and business expansion.
  Option E is about the value of hand-washing in preventing disease.
  None of these options are similar to the student's flawed pattern of reasoning.
Action: Answer("C")

  This is a fallacy because some people may simply not have been exposed to a virulent strain of the microorganism or may have other factors that protect them from infection.
  The flawed pattern of reasoning in the student's argument is similar to that in option C: Isabel said that she would take the medication. Obviously, though, she did not do so, because medication either cures disease or alleviates its symptoms, and Isabel is still quite ill.
  This is a fallacy because there are many reasons why Isabel might still be ill, such as not taking the medication as prescribed or the medication being ineffective against her particular illness.
Action: Answer("C")
